title: Psalms Chapter 37 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 37 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 37 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 37.

questions.question: According to Psalms 37:3, what should one do to dwell in the land and be fed?
options: Trust in the LORD and do good
Fret not thyself because of evildoers
Delight thyself in the LORD
Commit thy way unto the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Trust in the LORD and do good
questions.explanation: Psalms 37:3 says, 'Trust in the LORD, and do good; so shalt thou dwell in the land, and verily thou shalt be fed.'

questions.question: What shall the LORD do if you commit your way unto Him according to Psalms 37:5?
options: Bring it to pass
Cut down the wicked
Give you riches
Make you prosperous
questions.correctAnswer: Bring it to pass
questions.explanation: Psalms 37:5 states, 'Commit thy way unto the LORD; trust also in him; and he shall bring it to pass.'

questions.question: In Psalms 37:1, what are we told not to be because of evildoers?
options: Fret not thyself
Rejoice
Ignore them
Hate them
questions.correctAnswer: Fret not thyself
questions.explanation: Psalms 37:1 says, 'Fret not thyself because of evildoers, neither be thou envious against the workers of iniquity.'

questions.question: What will the meek inherit according to Psalms 37:11?
options: The earth
Riches
Fame
The kingdom of heaven
questions.correctAnswer: The earth
questions.explanation: Psalms 37:11 states, 'But the meek shall inherit the earth; and shall delight themselves in the abundance of peace.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 37:21, what is the behavior of the righteous compared to the wicked?
options: The righteous show mercy and give; the wicked borrow and do not repay
The righteous borrow and do not repay; the wicked give generously
Both borrow but only the wicked repay
Both give generously
questions.correctAnswer: The righteous show mercy and give; the wicked borrow and do not repay
questions.explanation: Psalms 37:21 says, 'The wicked borroweth, and payeth not again: but the righteous sheweth mercy, and giveth.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 37:7 advises to fret yourself because the wicked prosper in their way.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 37:7 states, 'Rest in the LORD, and wait patiently for him: fret not thyself because of him who prospereth in his way.'

questions.question: What will happen to the wicked according to Psalms 37:20?
options: They shall perish and consume away into smoke
They will inherit the earth
They will be blessed
They shall multiply
questions.correctAnswer: They shall perish and consume away into smoke
questions.explanation: Psalms 37:20 says, 'But the wicked shall perish, and the enemies of the LORD shall be as the fat of lambs: they shall consume; into smoke shall they consume away.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 37:24, what happens though a good man falls?
options: He shall not be utterly cast down
He will remain fallen
He will be condemned
He will be forgotten
questions.correctAnswer: He shall not be utterly cast down
questions.explanation: Psalms 37:24 states, 'Though he fall, he shall not be utterly cast down: for the LORD upholdeth him with his hand.'

questions.question: What does Psalms 37:29 say the righteous shall do?
options: Inherit the land and dwell therein forever
Be cut off
Be conquered
Flee the land
questions.correctAnswer: Inherit the land and dwell therein forever
questions.explanation: Psalms 37:29 says, 'The righteous shall inherit the land, and dwell therein for ever.'

questions.question: What does Psalms 37:4 say will happen if you delight yourself in the LORD?
options: He shall give thee the desires of thine heart
You will be wealthy
Your enemies will be defeated
You will never suffer
questions.correctAnswer: He shall give thee the desires of thine heart
questions.explanation: Psalms 37:4 states, 'Delight thyself also in the LORD; and he shall give thee the desires of thine heart.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 37:33 says the LORD will condemn the righteous when judged.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 37:33 says, 'The LORD will not leave him in his hand, nor condemn him when he is judged.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 37:18, what does the LORD know?
options: The days of the upright
The plans of the wicked
The thoughts of the proud
The sins of all men
questions.correctAnswer: The days of the upright
questions.explanation: Psalms 37:18 states, 'The LORD knoweth the days of the upright: and their inheritance shall be for ever.'

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Psalms 37:23: 'The steps of a good man are ordered by the ______.'
options: LORD
people
king
enemy
questions.correctAnswer: LORD
questions.explanation: Psalms 37:23 says, 'The steps of a good man are ordered by the LORD: and he delighteth in his way.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 37:25 says the righteous are often forsaken and their children beg for bread.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 37:25 states, 'I have been young, and now am old; yet have I not seen the righteous forsaken, nor his seed begging bread.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 37:30, what does the mouth of the righteous speak?
options: Wisdom
Lies
Complaints
Praises to kings
questions.correctAnswer: Wisdom
questions.explanation: Psalms 37:30 says, 'The mouth of the righteous speaketh wisdom, and his tongue talketh of judgment.'

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 37 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 37 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer feels envious of those who prosper through wrongdoing. Based on Psalms 37, what biblical truth would you share about handling envy and trust?
options: Fret not yourself because evildoers shall soon be cut down
Focus on gaining riches to match the wicked
Ignore the situation and seek your own success
Compete with evildoers to prove your worth
questions.correctAnswer: Fret not yourself because evildoers shall soon be cut down
questions.explanation: Psalms 37:1-2 teaches not to fret or be envious because the wicked will fade quickly like grass. Trusting God rather than envying protects our heart. Related verses: 37:7, 37:9, 37:10.

questions.question: How does Psalms 37 instruct us to respond when we face delays in seeing God's promises fulfilled?
options: Rest in the LORD and wait patiently for him
Take matters into your own hands quickly
Give up hope and seek other solutions
Express anger and frustration openly
questions.correctAnswer: Rest in the LORD and wait patiently for him
questions.explanation: Psalms 37:7 encourages resting in the LORD and waiting patiently, trusting His timing instead of reacting with anger or impatience. See also 37:5 and 37:34.

questions.question: What does Psalms 37:4 teach about delighting in the LORD and how it affects our desires?
options: He shall give thee the desires of thine heart
Our desires will always be ignored
We must earn our desires by works
Delight has no connection to desires
questions.correctAnswer: He shall give thee the desires of thine heart
questions.explanation: Psalms 37:4 promises that delighting in God aligns our hearts with His will, resulting in receiving the desires He approves. Verses 37:5 and 37:6 reinforce trust and commitment.

questions.question: According to Psalms 37, what is the outcome for the meek in contrast to the wicked?
options: The meek shall inherit the earth and delight in peace
The meek shall be oppressed forever
The wicked shall prosper eternally
The meek will gain riches by their own strength
questions.correctAnswer: The meek shall inherit the earth and delight in peace
questions.explanation: Psalms 37:11 teaches the meek will inherit the earth and enjoy peace, while 37:9, 37:38 describe the fate of the wicked being cut off. This reveals God's justice and blessing for humility.

questions.question: How does Psalms 37 counsel us to live in regard to anger and evil deeds?
options: Cease from anger and forsake wrath; fret not to do evil
Express anger to correct wrongs
Hold grudges to protect yourself
Use anger as a tool to fight evil
questions.correctAnswer: Cease from anger and forsake wrath; fret not to do evil
questions.explanation: Psalms 37:8 instructs believers to abandon anger and avoid evil, promoting peace and integrity. This aligns with the call to trust God rather than taking vengeance (37:7, 37:34).

questions.question: What does Psalms 37 say about the possessions of the righteous compared to the wicked?
options: A little that a righteous man hath is better than the riches of many wicked
The wicked always have more valuable possessions
The righteous should seek to have more than the wicked
Possessions do not matter to either
questions.correctAnswer: A little that a righteous man hath is better than the riches of many wicked
questions.explanation: Psalms 37:16 highlights the value of righteousness over wealth, emphasizing contentment and God's blessing rather than material abundance. Related: 37:17, 37:25.

questions.question: Based on Psalms 37, what encouragement can be given to someone who fears falling into sin or failure?
options: Though he fall, he shall not be utterly cast down; the LORD upholdeth him
If he falls, he is lost forever
Falling means God has rejected him
He should isolate himself to avoid sin
questions.correctAnswer: Though he fall, he shall not be utterly cast down; the LORD upholdeth him
questions.explanation: Psalms 37:24 provides assurance that God sustains the righteous even in failure, encouraging perseverance and trust in God's support. See also 37:23 and 37:40.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 37, the LORD forsakes His saints and allows their enemies to triumph permanently.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 37:28 states that the LORD loves justice, does not forsake His saints, and preserves them forever, while the wicked are cut off. This shows God's protection over His people.

questions.question: A believer is worried about being forsaken in times of need. What reassurance does Psalms 37 offer?
options: I have not seen the righteous forsaken, nor his seed begging bread
God will only help if they are wealthy
They must rely on themselves only
They will face eternal poverty
questions.correctAnswer: I have not seen the righteous forsaken, nor his seed begging bread
questions.explanation: Psalms 37:25 gives a personal testimony of God's faithfulness to provide for the righteous and their descendants, reassuring through God's provision. Also see 37:18 and 37:19.

questions.question: How does Psalms 37 teach us about generosity and mercy?
options: The righteous show mercy and lend, while the wicked borrow and do not repay
Lending is discouraged as it leads to loss
Mercy is only for close friends
Borrowing without repayment is acceptable for the righteous
questions.correctAnswer: The righteous show mercy and lend, while the wicked borrow and do not repay
questions.explanation: Psalms 37:21 highlights the contrast between righteous generosity and wicked irresponsibility, encouraging kindness and faithful stewardship. See also 37:26.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'The steps of a good man are ordered by the ________: and he delighteth in his way.'
options: LORD
people
wisdom
fortune
questions.correctAnswer: LORD
questions.explanation: Psalms 37:23 states that the LORD orders the steps of the good man, emphasizing divine guidance and the joy it brings. This highlights trust and obedience.

questions.question: What does Psalms 37 say about the words spoken by the righteous?
options: The mouth of the righteous speaketh wisdom, and his tongue talketh of judgment
The righteous remain silent in all matters
Their speech is harsh and condemning
They only speak about worldly things
questions.correctAnswer: The mouth of the righteous speaketh wisdom, and his tongue talketh of judgment
questions.explanation: Psalms 37:30 teaches that the righteous speak wisely and justly, reflecting their inner obedience and God's law within their hearts (37:31).

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 37, the wicked will ultimately consume away like smoke and perish.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 37:20 describes the fate of the wicked as perishing and consuming away like smoke, illustrating God's judgment on evil. See also 37:10 and 37:38.

questions.question: How does Psalms 37 describe God's protection over the righteous when they face enemies?
options: The LORD will not leave him in his hand, nor condemn him when he is judged
The righteous are left to fight alone
Enemies always triumph over the righteous
Protection depends on the righteous's power
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD will not leave him in his hand, nor condemn him when he is judged
questions.explanation: Psalms 37:33 assures that God defends the righteous, delivering them from their enemies and ensuring they are not condemned unjustly. See also 37:39 and 37:40.

questions.question: What is the ultimate blessing promised to those who trust and wait on the LORD according to Psalms 37?
options: They shall inherit the land and dwell therein forever
They will gain immediate worldly success
They will be free from all troubles
They will avoid all hardship
questions.correctAnswer: They shall inherit the land and dwell therein forever
questions.explanation: Psalms 37:29 and 37:34 promise inheritance of the land as a blessing to the righteous who trust God and keep His way, highlighting eternal security over temporary gains.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 37 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 37.

questions.question: In Psalms 37, what literary device is primarily used to contrast the fate of the wicked and the righteous?
options: Parallelism
Chiasm
Typology
Allegory
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: Psalms 37 extensively uses parallelism, especially antithetic parallelism, to contrast the wicked and the righteous as seen throughout the chapter, such as in verses 9 and 11.

questions.question: Which Hebrew term conceptually underpins the exhortation to 'Trust in the LORD, and do good' in Psalms 37:3, reflecting a covenantal faithfulness?
options: Emunah (Faithfulness)
Chesed (Lovingkindness)
Shalom (Peace)
Tzedakah (Righteousness)
questions.correctAnswer: Emunah (Faithfulness)
questions.explanation: The command to trust (emunah) in the LORD in Psalms 37:3 reflects covenantal faithfulness, a key Hebrew concept emphasizing steadfast trust and loyalty to God.

questions.question: What theme present in Psalms 37:4 ('Delight thyself also in the LORD...') is echoed in the New Testament book of James concerning the desires of the heart?
options: Faith producing works
God granting wisdom
Desires fulfilled through delight in God
Endurance in trials
questions.correctAnswer: Desires fulfilled through delight in God
questions.explanation: Psalms 37:4 connects delighting in God with receiving heart’s desires; similarly, James 4:3 discusses asking with improper motives and the right alignment of desires with God’s will.

questions.question: How does the historical context of ancient Near Eastern agrarian society deepen the meaning of Psalms 37:2's imagery of evildoers being 'cut down like grass'?
options: Grass was a sacred plant
Grass symbolized impermanence and vulnerability
Grass was used in temple rituals
Grass represented wealth
questions.correctAnswer: Grass symbolized impermanence and vulnerability
questions.explanation: In ancient Near Eastern agrarian culture, grass and herbs were transient and easily withered, symbolizing the fleeting success and downfall of evildoers as in Psalms 37:2.

questions.question: Psalms 37:6 uses the images of light and noonday to describe what aspect of God's action?
options: His judgment and righteousness being revealed
His wrath upon the wicked
His creation of the heavens
His covenant promises
questions.correctAnswer: His judgment and righteousness being revealed
questions.explanation: Verse 6 states God will manifest righteousness like light and judgment like noonday, symbolizing clarity, purity, and certainty in divine justice.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 37 teaches that the wicked will ultimately prosper and remain in power indefinitely.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 37 repeatedly states the wicked will perish and be cut off, such as in verses 10 and 20, indicating their power is temporary.

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'meek' inheriting the earth in Psalms 37:11, considering Old Testament covenant themes?
options: It reflects the reversal of social order promised to God's covenant people
It refers only to the literal land of Israel
It is a call for political revolution
It promises wealth to the meek
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects the reversal of social order promised to God's covenant people
questions.explanation: The meek inheriting the earth is a motif of divine justice reversing worldly power, aligning with covenant promises of blessing the humble and faithful.

questions.question: How does the phrase 'The LORD shall laugh at him' in Psalms 37:13 serve as a form of divine irony or judgement in the Hebrew worldview?
options: It expresses God's mockery of the wicked’s futile plans
It signifies God’s joy in creation
It indicates a celebratory festival
It is a metaphor for God's silence
questions.correctAnswer: It expresses God's mockery of the wicked’s futile plans
questions.explanation: In Hebrew thought, God laughing at the wicked shows the futility of their evil plans and the certainty of divine judgement, as in verse 13.

questions.question: Which New Testament passage most directly echoes the promise of inheritance to the meek found in Psalms 37:11?
options: Matthew 5:5
Romans 8:17
Hebrews 11:1
James 1:12
questions.correctAnswer: Matthew 5:5
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:5 states, 'Blessed are the meek: for they shall inherit the earth,' directly reflecting Psalms 37:11.

questions.question: Psalms 37:21 contrasts the behavior of the wicked and the righteous regarding debts. What does this reveal about ancient Israelite values on social responsibility?
options: Righteousness includes showing mercy and repaying debts
Debts were considered unimportant
The wicked were praised for borrowing
Social responsibility was unrelated to faithfulness
questions.correctAnswer: Righteousness includes showing mercy and repaying debts
questions.explanation: Verse 21 condemns the wicked who borrow but do not repay and praises the righteous who show mercy and give, highlighting social ethics in Israelite society.

questions.question: What is the typological significance of the 'steps of a good man are ordered by the LORD' in Psalms 37:23 when compared to the New Testament concept of divine guidance?
options: It foreshadows the New Testament teaching on walking in the Spirit
It only refers to physical walking
It contradicts New Testament teachings
It relates solely to Old Testament law observance
questions.correctAnswer: It foreshadows the New Testament teaching on walking in the Spirit
questions.explanation: The ordered steps metaphor prefigures New Testament themes of divine guidance and living by the Spirit, implying God’s active role in the believer’s path.

questions.question: According to Psalms 37:25, what observation does the psalmist make about the sustenance of the righteous over a lifetime?
options: The righteous are not forsaken nor do their descendants beg bread
The righteous often suffer from famine
The wicked provide for the righteous
The righteous must always rely on charity
questions.correctAnswer: The righteous are not forsaken nor do their descendants beg bread
questions.explanation: The psalmist testifies in verse 25 that through his life experience, the righteous have been sustained and not left destitute.

questions.question: How does the imagery of the wicked’s weapons turning against themselves in Psalms 37:15 reflect ancient Near Eastern concepts of divine justice?
options: It symbolizes God’s intervention causing self-destruction of evil plans
It means the wicked win battles
It indicates a literal sword fight
It refers to weapons used in religious ceremonies
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes God’s intervention causing self-destruction of evil plans
questions.explanation: The verse uses poetic imagery common in ANE literature where divine justice causes the wicked’s tools of harm to backfire on them.

questions.question: What is the primary authorial intent behind the repeated exhortations to 'wait on the LORD' in Psalms 37 (e.g., verses 7, 9, 34)?
options: To encourage patient trust amid apparent injustice
To promote political rebellion
To teach agricultural practices
To discourage any action from the faithful
questions.correctAnswer: To encourage patient trust amid apparent injustice
questions.explanation: The psalm encourages believers to patiently trust God's timing and justice despite the prosperity of evildoers.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Psalms 37:39, 'But the salvation of the righteous is of the _____: he is their strength in the time of trouble.'
options: LORD
king
people
priest
questions.correctAnswer: LORD
questions.explanation: Verse 39 declares that the LORD is the source of salvation and strength for the righteous in trouble.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 37 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 37 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 37, what is the proper response towards evildoers and their apparent prosperity?
options: Fret not thyself and cease from anger
Envy their success and retaliate
Ignore them completely
Join them to gain prosperity
questions.correctAnswer: Fret not thyself and cease from anger
questions.explanation: Psalms 37:1 and 37:8 instruct believers not to fret or be angry because of evildoers, emphasizing patience and trust in God. This is consistent with Romans 12:19, Proverbs 3:5-6, and 1 Peter 2:23, which teach trusting God’s justice rather than seeking vengeance.

questions.question: What does Psalms 37:3 teach about the relationship between trusting the LORD and doing good?
options: Trust in the LORD and do good to dwell in the land and be fed
Trust in your own strength and accumulate wealth
Ignore the LORD and focus on personal gain
Trust in others and seek their approval
questions.correctAnswer: Trust in the LORD and do good to dwell in the land and be fed
questions.explanation: Psalms 37:3 connects trust in God with doing good, promising stability ('dwell in the land') and provision ('verily thou shalt be fed'). This aligns with Proverbs 16:3, Matthew 6:33, and Galatians 6:9, which affirm trusting God and living righteously leads to blessings.

questions.question: What promise is given to those who delight themselves in the LORD according to Psalms 37:4?
options: He shall give thee the desires of thine heart
They will never face trials
They will become rulers over others
They will be exempt from suffering
questions.correctAnswer: He shall give thee the desires of thine heart
questions.explanation: Psalms 37:4 promises that delighting in the LORD results in receiving the desires of the heart. This reflects a heart aligned with God's will, similar to promises in Jeremiah 29:13, Matthew 7:7, and John 15:7, where seeking God leads to fulfilled desires in accordance with His will.

questions.question: What is the significance of committing one's way to the LORD as described in Psalms 37:5?
options: The LORD will bring it to pass
One will face no opposition
Others will obey you immediately
You will gain worldly riches
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD will bring it to pass
questions.explanation: Psalms 37:5 teaches that committing our way to the LORD and trusting Him results in God accomplishing His purposes for us. This is consistent with Proverbs 16:9, Psalm 55:22, and Philippians 4:6-7, emphasizing God’s sovereign guidance and faithful provision.

questions.question: How does Psalms 37:6 describe the manifestation of righteousness and judgment from God?
options: As the light and the noonday
As darkness and mystery
As a whisper in the night
As thunder and lightning
questions.correctAnswer: As the light and the noonday
questions.explanation: Psalms 37:6 states God will bring forth righteousness and judgment as clearly and brilliantly as light at noonday, symbolizing clarity and certainty. This imagery corresponds with Isaiah 60:1, John 8:12, and 2 Corinthians 4:6, where God’s righteousness and truth shine brightly against darkness.

questions.question: What is the promised inheritance for those who wait upon the LORD according to Psalms 37:9 and 37:11?
options: They shall inherit the earth and delight in peace
They will be taken away quickly
They will inherit wealth and power only
They will be hidden from the world
questions.correctAnswer: They shall inherit the earth and delight in peace
questions.explanation: Psalms 37:9 and 37:11 affirm that the meek and those who wait on the LORD will inherit the earth and enjoy abundant peace. This promise is echoed in Matthew 5:5, Revelation 21:7, and Isaiah 65:17, emphasizing the eschatological hope for God’s people.

questions.question: How does Psalms 37:13 depict God's attitude towards the wicked who plot against the just?
options: The Lord shall laugh, seeing their day is coming
The Lord will ignore them
The Lord will reward them
The Lord will fear them
questions.correctAnswer: The Lord shall laugh, seeing their day is coming
questions.explanation: Psalms 37:13 shows God’s sovereign assurance and mockery toward the wicked, knowing their judgment is certain. This reflects themes in Job 41:11, Proverbs 1:26, and Luke 18:7, where God’s justice triumphs over evil.

questions.question: What warning and outcome does Psalms 37:15-17 give concerning the weapons and strength of the wicked?
options: Their sword enters their own heart and their bows are broken
They become invincible and conquer all
Their weapons multiply and succeed
They are strengthened by their own devices
questions.correctAnswer: Their sword enters their own heart and their bows are broken
questions.explanation: Psalms 37:15-17 warns that the wicked’s weapons will harm themselves and their power will be broken, illustrating divine justice. This corresponds with Isaiah 49:4, Romans 12:19, and Revelation 19:11, where God overturns evil plans.

questions.question: How does Psalms 37:16 compare the possessions of the righteous to those of the wicked?
options: A little that a righteous man hath is better than the riches of many wicked
Righteousness depends on great wealth
The wicked's riches are the sign of blessing
Righteousness and riches are unrelated
questions.correctAnswer: A little that a righteous man hath is better than the riches of many wicked
questions.explanation: Psalms 37:16 values righteousness over material abundance, affirming spiritual wealth surpasses worldly riches. This is consistent with Proverbs 16:8, Luke 12:15, and 1 Timothy 6:6, which teach contentment and godliness over wealth.

questions.question: What does Psalms 37:21 say about the behavior of the wicked versus the righteous in terms of lending and mercy?
options: The wicked borrow and pay not again; the righteous show mercy and give
The wicked give generously; the righteous withhold mercy
Both wicked and righteous repay debts equally
The righteous borrow; the wicked lend without mercy
questions.correctAnswer: The wicked borrow and pay not again; the righteous show mercy and give
questions.explanation: Psalms 37:21 contrasts the wicked’s dishonesty with the righteous’ generosity and mercy. This aligns with Luke 6:35, Proverbs 28:27, and 2 Corinthians 9:7, emphasizing godly stewardship and compassion.

questions.question: According to Psalms 37:23-24, what sustains the steps of a good man even if he falls?
options: The LORD upholds him with His hand
His own strength and wisdom
The help of his friends
Fortune and luck
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD upholds him with His hand
questions.explanation: Psalms 37:23-24 teaches that God orders the steps of the righteous and sustains them even in failure. This truth is reflected in Proverbs 3:5-6, Isaiah 41:10, and Hebrews 13:5, emphasizing God’s faithful support.

questions.question: What testimony does Psalms 37:25 provide about the experience of the righteous over a lifetime?
options: The righteous are not forsaken nor their seed begging bread
The righteous always live without hardship
The righteous accumulate great wealth easily
The righteous are isolated and forgotten
questions.correctAnswer: The righteous are not forsaken nor their seed begging bread
questions.explanation: Psalms 37:25 affirms God’s provision for the righteous and their descendants, a testimony of divine faithfulness. This corresponds with Deuteronomy 28:12, Matthew 6:25-34, and Philippians 4:19 about God’s care.

questions.question: What does Psalms 37:28 reveal about God's relationship to judgment and His saints?
options: The LORD loveth judgment and forsaketh not His saints; they are preserved forever
God abandons the saints in judgment
Judgment is arbitrary and unpredictable
The saints must judge themselves
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD loveth judgment and forsaketh not His saints; they are preserved forever
questions.explanation: Psalms 37:28 emphasizes God's love for justice and His eternal preservation of the saints, consistent with Isaiah 54:17, Romans 8:31-39, and Jude 1:24, affirming God’s protective covenant.

questions.question: How does Psalms 37:30-31 characterize the speech and inward life of the righteous?
options: The mouth speaks wisdom and the law of God is in the heart
The mouth is silent and the heart is cold
The righteous only speak in parables
The law is only spoken, not internalized
questions.correctAnswer: The mouth speaks wisdom and the law of God is in the heart
questions.explanation: Psalms 37:30-31 highlight the righteous person’s wisdom in speech and internalization of God’s law, reflecting Psalm 1:2, Jeremiah 31:33, and Romans 7:22, teaching the renewing work of God's word in the believer.

questions.question: What assurance does Psalms 37:33-34 give regarding the fate of the righteous amid wicked opposition?
options: The LORD will not leave the righteous in the hand of the wicked and will exalt them
The righteous will be abandoned and fall
The wicked will always triumph
The righteous must fight alone
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD will not leave the righteous in the hand of the wicked and will exalt them
questions.explanation: Psalms 37:33-34 assure believers of God’s protection and exaltation despite wicked attacks, resonating with Psalm 121:7-8, Isaiah 54:17, and 1 Peter 5:10, affirming divine deliverance.
